text: this week's movies
Gloria stranger by the lake visitors
directed by godfrey reggio with a score
by Philip Glass visitors consists of 74
shots in his review Stephen Holden
writes there is no narrative art to the
imagery that might be described as a
very sophisticated Rorschach test with
an environmentalist subtext the first
image of the film is a gorilla staring
into the camera that's simian observer
lingers in your mind conjuring thoughts
of evolution and the balance between the
rational and beastial aspects of human
nature
the title visitors implies that aliens
are the subjects if so might they be
ourselves
is it you sir no for the neighbors
London lady Inanna Paulo stranger by the
lake is about a secluded beach where gay
men go to cruise and a series of crimes
that happen there in his review a Oh
Scott writes names are supplied very
late in the game and identities are left
behind the director traces a dialectic
of anonymity and intimacy stranger by
the lake is seductive and fascinating
but it is also a bit trapped in its own
conceit and in its carefully maintained
emotional detachment the film which
might have been provocatively terrifying
settles for being memorably strange
just got you who stepped on my lad
Gloria is about a middle-aged woman long
divorced in search of love and
fulfillment in his review AO Scott
writes the great accomplishment of
Gloria and astute unpretentious and
thrillingly humane film is that it
acknowledges both sides of its heroines
temperament without judgment or
sentimentality one of the delights of
the film is that it's richly detailed
realism as fuel for thought about Chile
men and women about how the cycle is a
family life haven't have not changed as
a result of sexual liberation in
consumer capitalism but the director is
wise enough to avoid overthinking or
being didactic he's interested above all
in showing Gloria exactly as she is
